page.title: 01FLIGHT OF THE GROUSE MOOR
page.content: The area comprises mainly young coniferous plantations. Previously it was high moorland. Sheep, grouse and curlew are almost gone and roe deer have appeared. It is thought the climate has also become milder. Wilsantown was the site of an early ironworks, the remains of which were destroyed by the Forestry Commission. Wilsantown is now about twenty houses. Blimpy is a group of houses built by the old coal company. The pits have been closed for many years, but one private mine operates. Part of Forth is in the block, it contains the school and some housing. No new local industries have developed. The landscape is rural. Public Transport is bus, poor and expensive. More private housing is appearing and local authority housing is being modernised. The source of the River Mause is now
